body.json:
{
    "title": "The Whispers Behind the Walls",
    "script": "Ethan had always felt uneasy in his new apartment.
There was something about the walls—the way they seemed to hum at night, as if the building itself was trying to speak to him.
At first, he blamed the old pipes or the neighbors he’d never met.
But as the nights dragged on, the humming grew louder.
And it wasn’t just humming anymore.

It started on a rainy Thursday night.
The wind rattled the cracked windowpane, and the streetlights flickered like dying stars.
Ethan sat alone, his eyes heavy with sleep, the TV casting pale blue light across the room.
That’s when he heard it.
A soft voice, almost a sigh, drifting through the wall behind his bed.
“Why did you come here?” it whispered.

Ethan froze.
He muted the TV and strained to listen.
Nothing but the patter of rain.
He shook his head and laughed nervously.
Just my imagination, he thought.
But the voice came again, clearer this time.
“Leave... before it’s too late.”

The next morning, Ethan convinced himself it had been a dream.
He went to work, tried to ignore the bags under his eyes, the way his hands trembled when he held his coffee.
But that night, as he lay in bed, the whispers returned.
They came from the walls, the floor, even the ceiling.
And they weren’t alone.

Scratching.
Like fingernails dragging against wood.
Soft at first, then desperate.
Ethan leapt from bed, his heart pounding in his chest.
He grabbed a flashlight and shone it around the room.
Nothing.
But the sounds didn’t stop.
They followed him wherever he went.

Days turned into sleepless nights.
Ethan stopped going to work.
He spent his time pacing, listening, waiting for the next voice, the next scratch.
He tore at the wallpaper, searching for hidden speakers, for anything that could explain what was happening.
All he found was rot and decay.

One night, driven to the edge, Ethan decided to confront whatever haunted him.
He stood before the closet, the source of the loudest whispers.
The door creaked as he opened it, revealing darkness deeper than night.
He stepped inside.

The door slammed shut behind him.
He fumbled for his flashlight, but it slipped from his shaking hands.
The whispers surrounded him, louder than ever.
He covered his ears, but they echoed in his mind.

“You can’t escape.”
“You shouldn’t have come.”
“Now you’re one of us.”

The air grew colder, the darkness thicker.
Ethan felt the walls closing in.
He pounded on the door, screaming for help.
But no one came.
The last thing he heard before the darkness swallowed him was a soft, hollow laughter.

Days later, the landlord opened the apartment to show it to a new tenant.
The rooms were empty.
No sign of Ethan.
Just the faint sound of whispers, and the hum of the walls.
"
}
